Description: Research over the past two decades has affirmed T cells as central mediators of host immunity to cancer. This session will explore recent advances in understanding how T cells are optimally activated, which mediators are most critical for their function, and what subsets provide the most durable anti-tumor responses. Focusing on negative checkpoints, studies will address the molecular mechanism whereby LAG3 inhibits T cell activation and illustrate how structural biology can optimize the development of immune-based therapies. In addressing effector mechanisms, the dual role of IFN and T cells in cancer immunotherapy will be presented, with a focus on underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms. Lastly, studies will address the role of resident memory T cells and mechanisms underlying tissue-localized recall responses to cancer. By extending work from mouse models to patients, this work will also address potential clinical approaches to improve T cell function against cancer.
